Give me recipe for Paneer Butter Masala

Ingredients:

For the Paneer Marinade:

250g paneer, cut into cubes
1/2 cup yogurt
1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste
1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder
1 teaspoon red chili powder
Salt to taste
For the Gravy:

2 tablespoons butter
1 tablespoon oil
1 cup onion, finely chopped
1 tablespoon ginger-garlic paste
1 cup tomato puree
1/2 cup cashew nuts, soaked in water
1 teaspoon red chili powder (adjust to taste)
1 teaspoon garam masala
1 teaspoon coriander powder
1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder
Salt to taste
1 cup water (adjust for desired consistency)
2 tablespoons fresh cream
1 teaspoon sugar (optional, to balance the acidity of tomatoes)
For Garnish:

Fresh coriander leaves, chopped
1 tablespoon butter (optional)
Instructions:

Marinate the Paneer:

In a bowl, mix yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt.
Add paneer cubes to the marinade, ensuring each piece is well-coated.
Allow it to marinate for at least 30 minutes.
Prepare the Cashew Paste:

Grind the soaked cashew nuts into a smooth paste using a little water. Set aside.
Cook the Paneer:

Heat 1 tablespoon of butter in a pan and fry the marinated paneer cubes until they turn golden brown. Set aside.
Prepare the Gravy:

In the same pan, add 1 tablespoon of oil and another tablespoon of butter.
Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for a minute until the raw smell disappears.
Add tomato puree and cook until the oil starts to separate from the masala.
Add red chili powder, garam masala, coriander powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Cook for a few minutes.
Finish the Curry:

Add the cashew paste and mix well.
Pour in water to achieve the desired consistency and bring the curry to a simmer.
Add the fried paneer cubes and cook for a few more minutes.
Stir in fresh cream and sugar (if using) to balance the flavors.
Garnish and Serve:

Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and a dollop of butter.
Serve hot with naan, roti, or rice.
Enjoy your homemade Paneer Butter Masala

Give me recipe for Jalebi

Ingredients:

2 cups all-purpose flour
1 cup yogurt
1/2 teaspoon baking soda
1 cup water
1 pinch saffron strands
Oil for frying
For Sugar Syrup:

2 cups sugar
1 cup water
1/2 teaspoon cardamom powder
Instructions:

Mix flour, yogurt, baking soda, and water to make a smooth batter. Allow it to ferment for 8 hours or overnight.
Prepare sugar syrup by dissolving sugar in water. Add saffron strands and cardamom powder. Boil until it reaches a sticky consistency.
Heat oil in a pan. Pour the batter into a jalebi dispenser and make circular shapes in the hot oil.
Fry until golden brown, then dip in sugar syrup for a few seconds.
Serve hot and enjoy the sweet and tangy Jalebi!

Serve hot with mint chutney and lemon wedges.

Instructions:

In a pan, heat ghee and oil. Sauté onions until golden brown.
Add tomatoes, mint, and coriander leaves. Cook until tomatoes are soft.
Add marinated chicken and cook until it's almost done.
In a separate pot, boil 4 cups of water. Add soaked and drained rice, salt, and cook until 70% done.
Layer half-cooked rice over the chicken in the pan. Sprinkle garam masala.
Cover and cook on low heat for 15-20 minutes.
Serve hot with raita.

Salt to taste
Instructions:

Serve hot. Tamarind rice is great for picnics and travel, as it stays flavorful even when cold.

Give me recipe for Kadhi

Ingredients:

1 cup yogurt
2 tablespoons gram flour
1 tablespoon oil
1 teaspoon mustard seeds
1 teaspoon cumin seeds
A pinch of asafoetida
8-10 curry leaves
2 green chilies, slit
1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder
1 teaspoon red chili powder
Salt to taste
2 cups water
For Pakoras:
1/2 cup gram flour
1 onion, finely chopped
1/2 teaspoon cumin powder
1/2 teaspoon red chili powder
Salt to taste
Water to make a thick batter
Oil for frying
Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
Instructions:

In a bowl, whisk together yogurt, gram flour, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt.
Heat oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, asafoetida, curry leaves, and green chilies.
Pour the yogurt mixture into the pan and stir continuously.
Add water gradually and let it simmer on low heat.
For pakoras, mix gram flour, chopped onions, cumin powder, red chili powder, salt, and water to form a thick batter.
Drop spoonfuls of the batter into hot oil and fry until golden brown.
Add the pakoras to the kadhi and simmer for an additional 10 minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve hot with rice.

Give me recipe for Pani Puri

Ingredients:

For Puris:
1 cup semolina (sooji)
1/4 cup all-purpose flour (maida)
Water to knead the dough
Oil for frying
For Pani:
1/2 cup mint leaves
1/4 cup coriander leaves
2 green chilies
1 teaspoon ginger paste
1 teaspoon tamarind paste
1 teaspoon chaat masala
1/2 teaspoon black salt
Salt to taste
For Filling:
Boiled and mashed potatoes
Boiled chickpeas
Tamarind chutney
Instructions:

For Puris:
Mix semolina and all-purpose flour. Knead into a stiff dough using water.
Divide the dough into small balls and roll them into puris.
Deep fry until they puff up and turn golden brown.
For Pani:
